text: mr. Lautenberg mr. Lautenberg I mr.
Cornyn mr. Cornyn I so today the Senate
echo ena moved by the House of
Representatives several weeks ago passed
a new piece of credit card legislation
that creates a number of new rules that
the industry will have to abide by in an
attempt to create a more consumer
friendly environment in fact there are
at least nine important aspects of this
and we're going to go after them one by
one first of all retroactive rate
increases now the way this tended to
work was that if you got into trouble
with the card company they would say to
you hey you know what you've done
something wrong and we're going to raise
your interest rate on the balance and
the debt that you've already run up well
now it's going to take at least 30 days
before they can do that to you at least
in the House version and 60 days if you
haven't made any payment in the Senate
version number two they want to reward
good behavior at least the Senate does
in their version so the way that happens
is that if you have paid your bill on
time for six months the Senate wants the
credit card company if they've already
raised your rate to consider giving you
a break and lower it again now the
45-day rule that's number three here and
all this means is that if they're going
to make any kind of major change they
need to give you 45 days notice number
four it's what i like to call nonsense
there's a lot of billing nonsense kind
of ugly practices in the car dentistry
one of the things they do is that they
may only give you 14 days from when they
send the bill to when the due date is
well now that requirement is 21 days
they have to send it out that far in
advance you aren't stuck paying late
fees now high interest first so the way
this happens is a lot of people end up
with a bunch of different rates on their
debt well what's going to happen now is
that when you send your check in and
it's more than the minimum payment
they're going to apply the money to the
highest interest debt first which helps
the consumers okay over-the-limit fees
so this is among the most noxious
charges that the credit card industry
levies well now it's going to happen is
that if you want the privilege of paying
that fee you're going to have to opt in
and
raise your hand and say yes I want the
option of going over my limit next up
student credit cards it's going to be
harder to get a credit card if you're a
student congress wants to make
restrictions for people under 18 Senate
wants to do it for people who were under
21 you would need a cosigner like a
parent or a guardian or perhaps a spouse
if you happen to get married young okay
the fine print Congress helpfully
includes this provision that says that
in any card application or an any card
disclosure document the font has to be a
certain size so there won't be any more
fine print and finally we have gift
cards this is just in the Senate bill
senator schumer was a big fan of this he
doesn't much like gift cards so there's
a couple restrictions here no more
dormancy fees fees for lack of use
there's another issue now again in the
Senate with expiration dates well now
there's not going to be any more
expiration dates for at least five years
so all these things in aggregate are
designed to make the industry a lot more
consumer friendly there may be
unintended consequences here we'll have
to wait and see what those might be
